Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Plant Growth Chambers and Curriculum for Educational Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be the increase of student engagement in STEM topics, as well as stimulating student engagement in critical challenges such as space exploration, climate change, plant-focused genetic engineering and improvement, and feeding an ever-increasing global population. These deliverables will be implemented via a novel STEM curriculum and hardware kits to K-12 schools across the United States. The hardware/curriculum method of combination is purposefully designed to first grab student interest, then teach the required STEM coursework, and finally suggesting careers relevant to each STEM topic discussed. Encompassing all of this will be curriculum design and thorough documentation that does not put an additional workload on the teachers applying it to their classrooms. Planning for an impact further in the future, all of the hardware will collect data from and images of the experiments conducted within them.

This I-Corps project further develops a low cost, reusable plant growth chamber that features data collection and a controlled environment previously unavailable on the education market. The technology involved in this includes a single board computer, temperature/humidity sensors, photoperiod sensors, sensor-driven actuation of the temperature level and photoperiod, a camera with limited computer vision capabilities, and equipment to verify nutrient solution consistency. This combination of hardware allows the enthusiasm and distributed numerical power of the citizen scientist to be empowered with technical capability in a way that neither the plant science nor education communities have seen before. This will encourage and accelerate learning by allowing more reliable data collection of various defined growing environments in order to create more accurate plant growth recipes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this grant, the MARSfarm team (henceforth “the team”) participated in the 6-week I-Corps training program to learn how to apply lean startup methodology and business practices to their open-source plant growth chamber. The team conducted 113 customer discovery interviews and attended 9 trade shows as well as two weekend workshops in Chicago during that period of time. They aggressively iterated on a business model canvas as a team and worked closely with their Industry Mentor to rigorously test the assumptions of their model. The team successfully met the requirements of the 6-week course and more importantly was able to identify the market of Career and Technical Education to pursue with their venture.  

  

Prior to I-Corps, MARSfarm had struggled with whether their target market should be defined as “agriculture” or “education”. On day one of the program they were forced to pick one of these and after choosing education they immediately realized how many unanswered questions there were about how teachers would utilize their technology in classrooms. By changing their market every week, literally, the team began to understand the different types of educators - public, private, K-8, secondary, post-secondary, informal, etc. and how critical it would be to narrow their focus even further. They also developed a strong appreciation of how important it would be to find the right human customer within that institution who felt responsible for solving this problem and had the resources to do it.  

 

In the fourth week of the program, the team interviewed  several “Agricultural Educators” working in secondary schools teaching 9-12th grade. They explained that not only were they paid more than regular teachers that they had access to significant budgets compared to most other teachers at the same high-school which was a critical concern we had about the education market. They also are generally more involved in writing grants, both public and private, for large capital equipment expenses to purchase greenhouses or sensors for agriscience labs. We found this trend to be true across most of the United States and were amazed to discover that there are 13,287 agricultural educators working in Career and Technical Education (CTE) departments (Smith, Lawver, and Foster 2016; Foster, Lawver, and Smith 2014).   

 

The agriculture industry is going through a revolution in its utilization and integration of data to produce and optimize crops, but our education system lacks the tools and resources necessary to properly prepare the next generation of Agriculture students to meet this demand. Vocational agricultural education programs are not adequately preparing students for future careers in modern data-driven agriscience. To enable training in data-driven agriculture, low-cost tools that automate collection of relevant agriscience data are needed for education. These tools allow focus in the classroom to shift from manual data-collection to data analysis. Therefore, the target customers for our products are secondary schools and higher-education programs focused on agriscience, data science, or biological sciences. 

 

In the Fall of 2020, MARSfarm Corporation began selling their growth chamber which includes temperature, humidity, CO2 sensors, and RGB imaging. Data collected in the chamber is available to both teachers and students through a progressive web application. Due to Covid-19 and the necessity of remote learning they pre-sold dozens of units and as of 01/27/2021 have delivered products to more than 100 secondary schools across the United States, Canada, and Mexico.  

 

Broader Impacts 

The I-Corps program served as a very impactful professional development course for both the CO-Principal Investigator (CO-PI) and the Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) who are both young and early in their careers. Both of them have experience in manufacturing and agriculture but neither had any knowledge about the education industry, muchless that there was a segment of teachers also passionate about agriculture. The MARSfarm CO-PI was homeschooled and before this program had never sat in a high-school science classroom and literally had no knowledge of the target market they chose to pursue. The MARSfarm EL had very little public speaking experience and was not used to being the one to speak for the company or make decisions on the fly. He has stated many times that this program changed his life and gave him not only the knowledge to understand his business but the confidence to lead it.
